#Text=Set up Your Tattoo Machine
#Text=Ever wanted to do your own tattoos to yourself and friends ?
#Text=Tattoos flourish outside the tattoo parlors .
#Text=Home studios are sometimes how many current tattoo artists got their start .
#Text=Tattoo machines are easy to set up .
#Text=Make sure you are in a clean environment while setting up your tattoo machine .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Choosing the Parts
#Text=Buy a starter kit for a convenient option .
#Text=Starter kits are great because they offer all the parts you need for tattooing .
#Text=These kits are n’t high in quality , but they are great for beginning to operate and maintain a tattoo machine .
#Text=Consider the quality of your machine before tattooing anyone .
#Text=A set up that is cheaper could hurt or infect someone or result in a low-quality tattoo .
#Text=Purchase individual parts if you want them to last longer .
#Text=For those who want better quality parts , purchasing individual components is the path for you .
#Text=Buying individual parts gives you the freedom to choose the extensions that you want and set up the machine just the way you want them .
#Text=Also , individual parts generally need to be replaced less often than a starter kit .
#Text=Get the tools you need to set up the machine .
#Text=You 'll need an Allen key set and a small screwdriver , at the minimum .
#Text=Check out the kit instructions or look over the individual parts to determine if you 'll need any other tools to set up the machine .
#Text=Ask a professional for advice if you 're new to tattooing .
#Text=If you have a regular tattoo artist , open up a dialogue about home kits .
#Text=Artists who operate out of tattoo shops often have worked from home at some point .
#Text=They can offer valuable input .
#Text=Some professionals may even be willing to give you a tutorial on setting up the machine , for a fee .
#Text=Assembling the Machine
#Text=Sanitize your hands .
#Text=Tattoo machines need to be treated with the utmost care .
#Text=Take precaution before handling these machines .
#Text=Wash your hands with antibacterial soap or wear latex gloves .
#Text=Familiarize yourself with the machine .
#Text=The frame holds all the pieces together .
#Text=Then you have 2 electromagnetic coils which provide the power for the machine .
#Text=The coils rapidly move the armature bar , which is connected to a barred needle .
#Text=The power supply connects to the electromagnetic coils .
#Text=All of these components can be removed or replaced as needed .
#Text=Assemble the barrel .
#Text=Inspect the grip of the machine .
#Text=There are 2 sides of the grip for the tube and the machine 's tip .
#Text=Set these to the preferable length , and tighten the 2 screws on the grip .
#Text=On average , the needle should n't exceed the tip more than 2 mm and no less than 1 mm .
#Text=If there is excessive blood , then your needle is too long .
#Text=Set up the needle .
#Text=Take a look at the needles you received with the machine .
#Text=You should have a few different types and sizes of needles .
#Text=Install one of the needles by inserting it through the tube towards the tip .
#Text=Be careful not to dull a needle while assembling .
#Text=This could lead to a painful tattoo .
#Text=For example , RL ( round liner ) , RS ( round shader ) , M1 ( magnum 1 layer ) , M2 ( double magnum ) , RM ( round magnum ) , and F ( flat ) are all different kinds of needles .
#Text=The numbers indicate the size and tell how many needles there are .
#Text=Secure the nipple .
#Text=The nipple , also known as a grommet , secures the needle and grip to the machine ’s base .
#Text=Place a nipple on the armature bar pin .
#Text=Fasten the needle ’s round open end onto the nipple .
#Text=Adjust the needle .
#Text=Once you ’ve assembled the tube , you need to adjust the length of how much the needle is exposed .
#Text=You can adjust the needle ’s exposure by adjusting the tube vise .
#Text=The tube vise is the adjustable screw in between the armature and needle .
#Text=Putting Together the Power Station
#Text=Choose a power supply .
#Text=Power supplies vary in specifications and voltages .
#Text=Some starter kits come equipped with a power supply that is n't adjustable .
#Text=You can replace this with a different one , if desired .
#Text=Your power supply should n’t cost more than the tattoo machine .
#Text=Power supplies with analog or digital displays allow you to adjust the settings .
#Text=Examine the power supply .
#Text=Check the fuse .
#Text=Make sure you are running the proper voltage into your machine .
#Text=Most tattoo power supplies will have a regulated control for the amount of fuse and power going into your tattoo machine .
#Text=Some of the cheaper models do n’t have this feature .
#Text=Acquire a footswitch and a clip cord .
#Text=If your power supply does n't come with a footswitch , you ’ll need to buy one .
#Text=A footswitch is fairly inexpensive and does n't require a major setup .
#Text=You 'll also need a clip cord to attach the tattoo machine to the power supply .
#Text=Connecting the Parts
#Text=Connect your footswitch .
#Text=Attach your footswitch to the the power supply .
#Text=The footswitch activates and regulates the power from the power supply to the needle , similar to a sewing peddle .
#Text=Connect the machine to the power supply .
#Text=There is a clear location at the bottom of the machine for the clip cord to connect the machine to the power supply .
#Text=There should only be 2 inputs on the power supply itself .
#Text=Make sure you connect the cables in their proper location .
#Text=Test the machine .
#Text=Once everything is connected and assembled , you ’re ready to test the machine .
#Text=If you are worried about testing the tattoo machine on yourself , just turn everything on and examine it .
#Text=The needle should vibrate at a consistent speed ( without stopping ) upon pressing the footswitch .
#Text=Practice on fruit .
#Text=A good way to practice your art is by practicing on apples or pears .
#Text=The skin on apples and pears are similar to the human flesh .
#Text=If your fruits become damaged , then you 're puncturing the needle too deep .
#Text=Tips
#Text=If the machine does n't work you should try readjusting the contact point screw .
#Text=Some artists make machines that are ready to go , so check into this option for added convenience .
#Text=Quick Summary
